value.name: Covid Inquiry RECAP: Rishi Sunak denies calling free school meal parents 'freeloaders'
value.description: Rishi Sunak, who was branded 'Dr Death' by Government scientists, issued an apology to bereaved families at the start of his Covid Inquiry grilling

value.name: Starmer to say his changes to Labour have been ‘for working people’
value.description: Sir Keir Starmer will say his changes to Labour have been to “restore the party to the service of working people”, as he gives a keynote speech marking the four-year anniversary of the 2019 election. The Labour leader will on Tuesday appeal directly to Tory voters, promising a government dedicated to economic stability and the rule of law.

value.name: Keir Starmer set to attack Tory 'broken promises' on immigration
value.description: And, according to The Sun, Starmer is set to hit out at the Tories for breaking promises on immigration. He is also understood to claim that ministers have thrown open jobs to those coming from abroad rather than creating jobs and training those in the UK.

value.name: Tory rows over the Rwanda plan could sink Sunak
value.description: Its leadership may not say this outright, but that’s the message. Keir Starmer’s consistent line is that Labour would “smash the smuggling gangs” to stop the crossings in the English Channel and secure Britain’s borders. For him this means being ...

value.name: Britain won’t rejoin the EU for decades — if ever
value.description: Worse, it would divert attention and energy away from tackling many other economic and social challenges. Sir Keir Starmer knows this. Most important, the outcome would not be the UK’s to decide. The EU would want to be quite confident that the new ...

value.name: Green protectionism comes with big risks
value.description: Industrial policy is being tasked not just with firming up supply chains and redistribution, but also with accelerating the green transition. The solution is subsidies. Already these exist at scale, and with some success.

value.name: UK government snubs key NATO ally Greece over stolen Parthenon sculptures
value.description: The statues and friezes, which formed part of the Parthenon temple built in the fifth century BC, are known in the UK as the “Elgin marbles” because they were removed in the early 1800s by Lord Elgin,

value.description: Trades unionists in Croydon are calling on the management of Ruskin House – the HQ of trades unionism in the borough as well as the offices of the Morning Star newspaper – to cancel a

value.name: Beyond Bricks and Mortar: Understanding the Housing Crisis in the UK
value.description: The Right to Buy scheme, popularised by Thatcher, continued by Blair, and turbocharged by Cameron, is also a major contributor. Those in social housing were able to buy their houses at a discounted rate, which whilst increasing homeownership, significantly diminished the availability of affordable housing.

value.name: First Minister says 'tough times' have led to fall in popularity
value.description: Mark Drakeford addressed recent poll findings as he reflected on the past year with ITV Wales' Sharp End. | ITV News Wales

value.name: Here's Why You Should Never Boil Chopped Broccoli

value.name: Politics latest news: Tory rebels urge Sunak to pull Rwanda Bill
value.description: Only one in 200 migrant appeals against being sent to Rwanda would succeed under the Government’s new deportation plan, Grant Shapps has claimed. The Defence Secretary said Home Office modelling suggested the “vast majority” of appeals from asylum seekers attempting to block being sent to Rwanda would fail.

value.name: Labour MP presents bill to suspend UK arms sales to Israel
value.description: A LABOUR MP is set to present a bill to parliament to suspend the sale of arms to Israel. On Monday, Zarah Sultana, Labour MP for Coventry South, announced she would be presenting the Arms Trade (Inquiry and Suspension) Bill.

value.name: ‘We’ve got to make it harder for the charlatans’: Alastair Campbell on why and how politics needs to change
value.description: Abby Reyes sits down with the former spin doctor to discuss ‘disagreeing agreeably’, why the Tories need ‘jail’ and what Labour can improve on

value.name: Zarah Sultana presents bill to suspend arms sales to Israel
value.description: A LABOUR MP is set to present a bill to parliament to suspend the sale of arms to Israel. On Monday, Zarah Sultana, Labour MP for Coventry South, announced she would be presenting the Arms Trade (Inquiry and Suspension) Bill.

value.name: 'Rishi on the rack': what happens if PM loses Rwanda vote?
value.description: "Rishi on the rack" was Metro's front-page headline ahead of the PM being questioned on his flagship "Eat Out to Help Out" scheme and failure to provide the public inquiry with pandemic-era WhatsApp messages from his time as chancellor.

value.name: Rwanda row: PM Sunak, who pledged to ‘stop the boats’, faces crucial test
value.description: Sunak’s Conservatives criticise the plan to deport refugees from the UK to Rwanda as contradicting international law.

value.name: 🔒 Ending stagnation report reveals Britain’s economic decline, urges critical reforms – Matthew Brooker
value.description: In the wake of a revelation by London-based think tank The Resolution Foundation, Matthew Brooker dissects Britain's stark economic decline.

value.name: Corbyn joins pro-Palestine protest in Liverpool
value.description: HUNDREDS gathered outside Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral today to call for an end to Israel’s bombardment of Gaza. Among the speakers was Haneen Awaad, a Palestinian Liverpudlian from Scousers for Palestine, and former Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.

value.name: Sunak’s insistence he’s in control only proves he’s not
value.description: Conservative infighting risks obscuring any policy successes the Prime Minister enjoys.

value.name: Is Nigel Farage eyeing a return to UK politics? Maybe
value.description: The Brexit figurehead has in recent weeks teased the idea of rejoining the struggling ruling Conservative party, which he quit 30 years ago in protest over its stance on Europe.

value.name: Major Political Reform Could Secure Key Labour Target Voters, Study Suggests
value.description: Focus groups emphasised the lack of trust in politicians to deliver reform, but the findings point to a vote-winning opportunity for political parties, especially Labour, if they are able to prove that they are serious about reforming how politics is conducted, the campaign groups argue.

value.name: Keir Starmer set to attack Tory 'broken promises' on immigration

value.name: Behind the scenes: A billionaire at COP28
value.description: Australian tycoon Andrew Forrest has made a big bet — that after building a mining empire, his next fortune will come from the green transition.

value.name: Want to survive the apocalypse? Forget the Government’s new website, take my advice instead
value.description: It was at a visit this week to Porton Down, that science and technology campus in Wiltshire (where boffins create viruses and store vials of cholera, when they’re not fishing inside the brains of captured aliens) that Deputy PM Oliver Dowden let slip that he’s compiling a long and scary and frightening and secret list that he’ll reveal next year.

value.name: Is Britain ready to be honest about its decline?
value.description: Britain has strengths, particularly in services. The country is the world’s second-largest exporter of services after the US. This pillar of growth goes well beyond financial services, whose share of exports fell to 9% last year from 12 per cent in 2022.

value.name: Labour’s response to the Rwanda scheme is gutless and shameful
value.description: Labour’s alternative policy is that they would use “British policing and British intelligence to smash the gangs trafficking people across the Channel”.
